title: The mechanization of science illustrated by the Lean formalization of the multi-graded Proj construction
summary:
We formalize the multi-graded Proj construction in Lean4, illustrating
mechanized mathematics and formalization.

AI.tldr: The paper demonstrates the formalization of the multi-graded Proj construction in Lean4.
AI.motivation: The study aims to advance mechanized mathematics through the formalization of abstract algebraic structures.
AI.method: The multi-graded Proj construction is formalized using the Lean4 proof assistant.
AI.result: The successful representation of this mathematical concept in Lean4 showcases its capabilities for mechanized proof systems.
AI.conclusion: The work highlights tool developments in Lean4 for formalizing complex mathematical structures, benefiting educational and theoretical pursuits.

title: Mitigating data replication in text-to-audio generative diffusion models through anti-memorization guidance
summary:
A persistent challenge in generative audio models is data replication, where
the model unintentionally generates parts of its training data during
inference. In this work, we address this issue in text-to-audio diffusion
models by exploring the use of anti-memorization strategies. We adopt
Anti-Memorization Guidance (AMG), a technique that modifies the sampling
process of pre-trained diffusion models to discourage memorization. Our study
explores three types of guidance within AMG, each designed to reduce
replication while preserving generation quality. We use Stable Audio Open as
our backbone, leveraging its fully open-source architecture and training
dataset. Our comprehensive experimental analysis suggests that AMG
significantly mitigates memorization in diffusion-based text-to-audio
generation without compromising audio fidelity or semantic alignment.

AI.tldr: This paper addresses data replication in generative text-to-audio models using Anti-Memorization Guidance (AMG).
AI.motivation: To tackle the persistent problem of generative audio models unintentionally replicating parts of their training data during inference.
AI.method: The study adopts Anti-Memorization Guidance (AMG), a modified sampling technique in pre-trained diffusion models, and evaluates three types of guidance within AMG.
AI.result: The experiments demonstrate that AMG effectively reduces data replication while maintaining audio quality and semantic alignment.
AI.conclusion: Anti-Memorization Guidance can be a reliable strategy to mitigate memorization issues in text-to-audio diffusion models.

title: Exploring How Audio Effects Alter Emotion with Foundation Models
summary:
Audio effects (FX) such as reverberation, distortion, modulation, and dynamic
range processing play a pivotal role in shaping emotional responses during
music listening. While prior studies have examined links between low-level
audio features and affective perception, the systematic impact of audio FX on
emotion remains underexplored. This work investigates how foundation models -
large-scale neural architectures pretrained on multimodal data - can be
leveraged to analyze these effects. Such models encode rich associations
between musical structure, timbre, and affective meaning, offering a powerful
framework for probing the emotional consequences of sound design techniques. By
applying various probing methods to embeddings from deep learning models, we
examine the complex, nonlinear relationships between audio FX and estimated
emotion, uncovering patterns tied to specific effects and evaluating the
robustness of foundation audio models. Our findings aim to advance
understanding of the perceptual impact of audio production practices, with
implications for music cognition, performance, and affective computing.

AI.tldr: The paper explores how foundation models, pretrained on multimodal data, can analyze the emotional impact of audio effects like reverberation and distortion.
AI.motivation: To deepen the understanding of how audio effects systematically influence emotional perception in music, an area previously underexplored.
AI.method: The study leverages embeddings from foundation models and applies probing techniques to reveal relationships between audio effects and emotion.
AI.result: Nonlinear relationships between audio effects and estimated emotions were uncovered, demonstrating the utility of foundation models for analyzing sound design's emotional impact.
AI.conclusion: The research offers insights into the perceptual effects of audio production methods, contributing to fields like music cognition, performance, and affective computing.

title: Watermarking and Anomaly Detection in Machine Learning Models for LORA RF Fingerprinting
comment:
IEEE International Conference on Acoustics, Speech, and Signal
  Processing (ICASSP)
summary:
Radio frequency fingerprint identification (RFFI) distinguishes wireless
devices by the small variations in their analog circuits, avoiding heavy
cryptographic authentication. While deep learning on spectrograms improves
accuracy, models remain vulnerable to copying, tampering, and evasion. We
present a stronger RFFI system combining watermarking for ownership proof and
anomaly detection for spotting suspicious inputs. Using a ResNet-34 on log-Mel
spectrograms, we embed three watermarks: a simple trigger, an adversarially
trained trigger robust to noise and filtering, and a hidden gradient/weight
signature. A convolutional Variational Autoencoders (VAE) with Kullback-Leibler
(KL) warm-up and free-bits flags off-distribution queries. On the LoRa dataset,
our system achieves 94.6% accuracy, 98% watermark success, and 0.94 AUROC,
offering verifiable, tamper-resistant authentication.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces an enhanced Radio Frequency Fingerprint Identification (RFFI) system that integrates watermarking for ownership verification and anomaly detection for robustness, achieving a high accuracy, watermark success rate, and resistance to tampering.
AI.motivation: To improve authentication methods of wireless devices by using analog circuit variations while addressing vulnerabilities like copying, tampering, and evasion.
AI.method: The study combines watermarking (using triggers and gradient/weight signatures) with anomaly detection through Variational Autoencoders on log-Mel spectrograms, employing ResNet-34 for the learning model.
AI.result: The system demonstrated 94.6% accuracy in identifying devices, 98% watermark success in verifying ownership, and a 0.94 AUROC score in detecting suspicious inputs.
AI.conclusion: The proposed RFFI system is effective in providing secure, verifiable, and tamper-resistant authentication for wireless devices.

title: BabyHuBERT: Multilingual Self-Supervised Learning for Segmenting Speakers in Child-Centered Long-Form Recordings
summary:
Child-centered long-form recordings are essential for studying early language
development, but existing speech models trained on clean adult data perform
poorly due to acoustic and linguistic differences. We introduce BabyHuBERT, the
first self-supervised speech representation model trained on 13,000 hours of
multilingual child-centered long-form recordings spanning over 40 languages. We
evaluate BabyHuBERT on speaker segmentation, identifying when target children
speak versus female adults, male adults, or other children -- a fundamental
preprocessing step for analyzing naturalistic language experiences. BabyHuBERT
achieves F1-scores from 52.1% to 74.4% across six diverse datasets,
consistently outperforming W2V2-LL4300 (trained on English long-forms) and
standard HuBERT (trained on clean adult speech). Notable improvements include
13.2 absolute F1 points over HuBERT on Vanuatu and 15.9 points on Solomon
Islands corpora, demonstrating effectiveness on underrepresented languages. By
sharing code and models, BabyHuBERT serves as a foundation model for child
speech research, enabling fine-tuning on diverse downstream tasks.

AI.tldr: BabyHuBERT is a self-supervised speech model trained on 13,000 hours of child-centered recordings in 40+ languages, excelling in speaker segmentation for child speech analysis compared to prior models.
AI.motivation: Existing speech models struggle on child-centered data due to differences in acoustics and language, necessitating a new approach tailored for early language development analysis.
AI.method: The researchers developed a self-supervised speech representation model called BabyHuBERT, trained on a multilingual dataset of 13,000 hours of child-focused recordings. They tested its effectiveness on speaker segmentation tasks.
AI.result: BabyHuBERT outperformed W2V2-LL4300 and HuBERT models in speaker segmentation, with F1-scores ranging from 52.1% to 74.4% across six datasets. It showed notable improvement on underrepresented languages such as those in Vanuatu and Solomon Islands.
AI.conclusion: BabyHuBERT proves effective for child speech analysis, setting a new standard as a foundation model for this research domain and enabling further fine-tuning for various tasks.

title: Undersampled Phase Retrieval with Image Priors
summary:
Phase retrieval seeks to recover a complex signal from amplitude-only
measurements, a challenging nonlinear inverse problem. Current theory and
algorithms often ignore signal priors. By contrast, we evaluate here a variety
of image priors in the context of severe undersampling with structured random
Fourier measurements. Our results show that those priors significantly improve
reconstruction, allowing accurate reconstruction even below the weak recovery
threshold.

AI.tldr: This paper explores how incorporating image priors can improve phase retrieval performance under severe measurement undersampling.
AI.motivation: Current phase retrieval techniques often ignore signal priors, limiting reconstruction performance, especially in challenging scenarios such as severe undersampling.
AI.method: The authors assess various image priors in conjunction with structured random Fourier measurements to determine their efficacy in improving reconstruction during phase retrieval.
AI.result: Using image priors dramatically enhances reconstruction accuracy, even when measurements are significantly undersampled, surpassing the weak recovery threshold.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating image priors into phase retrieval algorithms is an effective strategy for improving reconstruction quality under challenging conditions.

title: TITAN: A Trajectory-Informed Technique for Adaptive Parameter Freezing in Large-Scale VQE
comment:
Accepted by The Thirty-Ninth Annual Conference on Neural Information
  Processing Systems (NeurIPS 2025)
summary:
Variational quantum Eigensolver (VQE) is a leading candidate for harnessing
quantum computers to advance quantum chemistry and materials simulations, yet
its training efficiency deteriorates rapidly for large Hamiltonians. Two issues
underlie this bottleneck: (i) the no-cloning theorem imposes a linear growth in
circuit evaluations with the number of parameters per gradient step; and (ii)
deeper circuits encounter barren plateaus (BPs), leading to exponentially
increasing measurement overheads. To address these challenges, here we propose
a deep learning framework, dubbed Titan, which identifies and freezes inactive
parameters of a given ansatze at initialization for a specific class of
Hamiltonians, reducing the optimization overhead without sacrificing accuracy.
The motivation of Titan starts with our empirical findings that a subset of
parameters consistently has a negligible influence on training dynamics. Its
design combines a theoretically grounded data construction strategy, ensuring
each training example is informative and BP-resilient, with an adaptive neural
architecture that generalizes across ansatze of varying sizes. Across benchmark
transverse-field Ising models, Heisenberg models, and multiple molecule systems
up to 30 qubits, Titan achieves up to 3 times faster convergence and 40% to 60%
fewer circuit evaluations than state-of-the-art baselines, while matching or
surpassing their estimation accuracy. By proactively trimming parameter space,
Titan lowers hardware demands and offers a scalable path toward utilizing VQE
to advance practical quantum chemistry and materials science.

AI.tldr: Titan is a deep learning framework addressing inefficiencies in Variational Quantum Eigensolver (VQE) by identifying and freezing inactive parameters, thus improving training speed and reducing circuit evaluations while maintaining accuracy.
AI.motivation: The motivation stems from the inefficiencies in VQE training due to the no-cloning theorem and barren plateaus in deeper circuits, which lead to high computational overheads.
AI.method: Titan employs a data construction strategy that avoids barren plateaus, paired with an adaptive neural architecture capable of identifying and freezing inactive parameters at initialization.
AI.result: Titan demonstrated up to 3 times faster convergence and 40-60% fewer circuit evaluations across multiple quantum models and molecular systems, without sacrificing accuracy.
AI.conclusion: Titan effectively reduces optimization overhead, hardware demands, and makes VQE more scalable for advancing quantum chemistry and materials science.

title: Physics-Informed GCN-LSTM Framework for Long-Term Forecasting of 2D and 3D Microstructure Evolution
summary:
This paper presents a physics-informed framework that integrates graph
convolutional networks (GCN) with long short-term memory (LSTM) architecture to
forecast microstructure evolution over long time horizons in both 2D and 3D
with remarkable performance across varied metrics. The proposed framework is
composition-aware, trained jointly on datasets with different compositions, and
operates in latent graph space, which enables the model to capture compositions
and morphological dynamics while remaining computationally efficient.
Compressing and encoding phase-field simulation data with convolutional
autoencoders and operating in Latent graph space facilitates efficient modeling
of microstructural evolution across composition, dimensions, and long-term
horizons. The framework captures the spatial and temporal patterns of evolving
microstructures while enabling long-range forecasting at reduced computational
cost after training.

AI.tldr: This paper integrates GCN with LSTM in a physics-informed framework to efficiently forecast long-term 2D/3D microstructure evolution.
AI.motivation: To model microstructural evolution across different compositions and dimensions while reducing computational costs.
AI.method: Combining graph convolutional networks (GCN) and long short-term memory (LSTM) within a physics-informed framework, operating in latent graph space, and using convolutional autoencoders.
AI.result: The framework demonstrated strong performance in forecasting microstructural evolution with reduced computational cost.
AI.conclusion: This approach captures complex spatial and temporal microstructural dynamics efficiently over long horizons and dimensions.

title: Real-Time Streaming Mel Vocoding with Generative Flow Matching
comment:

summary:
The task of Mel vocoding, i.e., the inversion of a Mel magnitude spectrogram
to an audio waveform, is still a key component in many text-to-speech (TTS)
systems today. Based on generative flow matching, our prior work on generative
STFT phase retrieval (DiffPhase), and the pseudoinverse operator of the Mel
filterbank, we develop MelFlow, a streaming-capable generative Mel vocoder for
speech sampled at 16 kHz with an algorithmic latency of only 32 ms and a total
latency of 48 ms. We show real-time streaming capability at this latency not
only in theory, but in practice on a consumer laptop GPU. Furthermore, we show
that our model achieves substantially better PESQ and SI-SDR values compared to
well-established not streaming-capable baselines for Mel vocoding including
HiFi-GAN.

AI.tldr: The paper presents MelFlow, a new streaming-capable generative vocoder for converting Mel spectrograms into audio with low latency and improved performance.
AI.motivation: To address the challenges of efficient, real-time Mel vocoding with low latency while surpassing existing baseline performances.
AI.method: The authors developed MelFlow, leveraging generative flow matching, DiffPhase for phase retrieval, and the pseudoinverse operator of the Mel filterbank.
AI.result: Demonstrates real-time streaming viability on a consumer GPU and achieves better PESQ and SI-SDR metrics than non-streaming baselines like HiFi-GAN.
AI.conclusion: MelFlow is a significant advancement in Mel vocoding, providing real-time capabilities with low latency and superior audio quality metrics.

title: Explicit Context-Driven Neural Acoustic Modeling for High-Fidelity RIR Generation
summary:
Realistic sound simulation plays a critical role in many applications. A key
element in sound simulation is the room impulse response (RIR), which
characterizes how sound propagates from a source to a listener within a given
space. Recent studies have applied neural implicit methods to learn RIR using
context information collected from the environment, such as scene images.
However, these approaches do not effectively leverage explicit geometric
information from the environment. To further exploit the potential of neural
implicit models with direct geometric features, we present Mesh-infused Neural
Acoustic Field (MiNAF), which queries a rough room mesh at given locations and
extracts distance distributions as an explicit representation of local context.
Our approach demonstrates that incorporating explicit local geometric features
can better guide the neural network in generating more accurate RIR
predictions. Through comparisons with conventional and state-of-the-art
baseline methods, we show that MiNAF performs competitively across various
evaluation metrics. Furthermore, we verify the robustness of MiNAF in datasets
with limited training samples, demonstrating an advance in high-fidelity sound
simulation.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces MiNAF, a method leveraging rough room geometry to improve neural RIR predictions.
AI.motivation: Existing neural methods for sound simulation cannot effectively use explicit geometric data from the environment.
AI.method: MiNAF uses rough room meshes and distance distributions to provide explicit local geometric features to a neural network for RIR prediction.
AI.result: MiNAF performs well across evaluation metrics and exhibits robustness even with limited training data.
AI.conclusion: Incorporating explicit geometric features enhances RIR prediction quality in neural-based sound simulations.

title: Shedding Light on Dark Matter at the LHC with Machine Learning
summary:
We investigate a WIMP dark matter (DM) candidate in the form of a
singlino-dominated lightest supersymmetric particle (LSP) within the
$Z_3$-symmetric Next-to-Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model. This framework
gives rise to regions of parameter space where DM is obtained via
co-annihilation with nearby higgsino-like electroweakinos and DM direct
detection~signals are suppressed, the so-called ``blind spots". On the other
hand, collider signatures remain promising due to enhanced radiative decay
modes of higgsinos into the singlino-dominated LSP and a photon, rather than
into leptons or hadrons. This motivates searches for radiatively decaying
neutralinos, however, these signals face substantial background challenges, as
the decay products are typically soft due to the small mass-splits ($\Delta m$)
between the LSP and the higgsino-like coannihilation partners. We apply a
data-driven Machine Learning (ML) analysis that improves sensitivity to these
subtle signals, offering a powerful complement to traditional search strategies
to discover a new physics scenario. Using an LHC integrated luminosity of
$100~\mathrm{fb}^{-1}$ at $14~\mathrm{TeV}$, the method achieves a $5\sigma$
discovery reach for higgsino masses up to $225~\mathrm{GeV}$ with $\Delta
m\!\lesssim\!12~\mathrm{GeV}$, and a $2\sigma$ exclusion up to
$285~\mathrm{GeV}$ with $\Delta m\!\lesssim\!20~\mathrm{GeV}$. These results
highlight the power of collider searches to probe DM candidates that remain
hidden from current direct detection experiments, and provide a motivation for
a search by the LHC collaborations using ML methods.

AI.tldr: This paper investigates a singlino-dominated dark matter candidate within the $Z_3$-symmetric NMSSM framework, utilizing machine learning to enhance discovery sensitivity at the LHC.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to explore a dark matter candidate that is inaccessible through current direct detection methods but could be detected through collider signatures, even with challenging small mass differences between particles.
AI.method: The authors employed a machine learning-based data-driven approach to improve detection sensitivity to radiative decays of neutralinos, analyzed under specific configurations of the NMSSM framework at the LHC with $100~\mathrm{fb}^{-1}$ luminosity.
AI.result: Using machine learning, the method achieved a $5\sigma$ discovery reach for higgsino masses up to $225~\mathrm{GeV}$ and a $2\sigma$ exclusion up to $285~\mathrm{GeV}$ for small mass differences.
AI.conclusion: This study demonstrates the effectiveness of machine learning in collider searches for elusive dark matter candidates, motivating further exploration of these techniques in LHC experiments.
